channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: China Sentences Man to Death for Espionage, Saying He Sold Secrets
item.description: The penalty for a computer technician accused of leaking 150,000 classified documents highlights the government’s campaign against security threats.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Australian Premier Malcolm Turnbull, Stymied by Senate, Calls for Vote
item.description: The election, to be held on July 2, will test Mr. Turnbull’s popularity with the public just seven months after taking office.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: In Farewell, Fidel Castro Urges Party to Fulfill His Vision
item.media:description: Fidel Castro, left, with his brother, President Raúl Castro, addressed Cuba’s Communist Party at the party congress in Havana on Tuesday.
item.description: While Mr. Castro, 89, seemed to take his leave of the party on Tuesday, others in his cohort signaled their intentions to stay put.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA BURNETT

item.title: Vote to Impeach Rousseff Prompted Cheers, But Won’t End Turmoil in Brazil
item.media:description: Opposition lawmakers celebrated after the lower house of Congress voted to impeach Brazil’s president, Dilma Rousseff, on Sunday.
item.description: On Monday, Brazilians awoke to the sobering reality that the political and economic turmoil that has consumed their country for the past two years is far from over.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS and VINOD SREEHARSHA

item.title: Earthquake Leaves a Trail of Destruction in Ecuador
item.media:description: Carlos Chávez watched over the wrapped body of his 31-year-old daughter, Vicky Chávez, on Monday after it was retrieved from the rubble of a building severely damaged by the earthquake in Portoviejo, Ecuador.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: Rescuers are still digging through the rubble from Saturday’s magnitude 7.8 quake, the strongest to strike Ecuador in decades.
item.dc:creator: MAGGY AYALA and KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Senator Says He May Back Bill Exposing Saudis to 9/11 Lawsuits
item.media:description: Senator Mitch McConnell, left, the majority leader, and Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas, leave a Senate policy luncheon on Tuesday. Mr. McConnell has declined to give his full support of the Sept. 11 bill, saying he would need to study the measure more carefully.
item.description: Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, said he would drop his opposition to the bill if its sponsors agreed to changes seeking to protect American interests abroad.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI and JENNIFER STEINHAUER

item.title: Obama to Visit a Saudi Arabia Deep in Turmoil
item.media:description: Saudi women and men on opposite sides of a hall at the American Express Luxury Expo in Riyadh last month.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: As the kingdom prepares to greet the president, it faces low oil prices, rising Iranian influence and fears of a widening rift with the United States.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and NICHOLAS KULISH
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Memo From Brussels: A Close Look at Brussels Offers a More Nuanced View of Radicalization
item.media:description: Residents at a market in Molenbeek, a heavily immigrant neighborhood of Brussels, last month.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: A look at Molenbeek and other parts of Brussels suggests that immigrants from North Africa, particularly Morocco, are angrier and more alienated than the city’s Turks.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Latvia Wants to Ban Face Veils, for All 3 Women Who Wear Them
item.media:description: Liga Legzdina, 27, who goes by the name Fatima, near Riga, Latvia. She is one of a tiny handful of women who wear the niqab in the country, and interactions on buses and trams, she said, often involve her being told to “go back to where you come from.”
item.media:credit: Reinis Hofmanis for The New York Times
item.description: A proposal to ban the veils, or niqabs, from public spaces is one expression of broader fears about immigration and Muslims in this small, homogeneous country.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD MARTYN-HEMPHILL
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Germany Cracks Down on Far Right With Arrests and a Trial
item.description: A raid in Saxony led to the arrest of five people suspected of attacking refugee shelters, and the trial of an anti-immigrant group leader began.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE and MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Syria Cease-Fire Crumbles as Bombings Kill Dozens
item.media:description: The remains of a market in Maarat al-Noaman, in Syria’s northern province of Idlib, after an airstrike Tuesday. Dozens of people were reported killed.
item.description: Government warplanes attacked the towns of Maarat al-Noaman and Kafr Nabl a day after the main Syrian opposition group said it would no longer participate in talks in Geneva.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Ukraine Leader Says Russia Appears to Agree to Prisoner Swap
item.media:description: Defendants Yevgeny Yerofeyev, left, and Aleksandr Aleksandrov sat in a cage during a trial session in Kiev, Ukraine, on April 15.
item.description: President Petro O. Poroshenko said that President Vladimir V. Putin “seemed” to approve of the deal that would bring home Lt. Nadiya V. Savchenko.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Replica of Palmyra Arch Is Unveiled in Trafalgar Square
item.media:description: A scale replica of a landmark Roman arch that was destroyed by Islamic State fighters in Palmyra, Syria, was unveiled in Trafalgar Square, in London, on Tuesday.
item.description: The marble copy of the landmark, which was destroyed by Islamic State fighters, was built from digital models and will be displayed in London through Thursday.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER D. SHEA

item.title: Candidates to Lead Philippines Seek to Tap Into Aquino Fatigue
item.media:description: Rodrigo Duterte, second from left atop the vehicle, campaigning for president of the Philippines at Cainta Rizal, east of Manila, last week.
item.description: President Benigno S. Aquino III has overseen nearly six years of strong growth, but many voters say his administration has been indecisive and ineffective.
item.dc:creator: FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: Israeli Convicted in Murder of Palestinian Teenager
item.media:description: The remains of Muhammad Abu Khdeir, 16, arriving in the Shuafat neighborhood of East Jerusalem before burial in July 2014.
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.description: A judge rejected an insanity defense by Yosef Haim Ben-David, who could face a life sentence for the abduction and death of Muhammad Abu Khdeir.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Sinosphere: Front-End Loaders in China Wage Heavy-Duty Combat Over Building Projects
item.description: Workers from one company had shown up at a concrete plant in a northern county intending to take over a new development project, the news media said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Taliban Send Message With Deadly Kabul Attack as Fighting Season Begins
item.description: A truck bomb that killed at least 30 people and wounded more than 300 underscored fears about the group’s ability to infiltrate the Afghan capital.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and AHMAD SHAKIB

item.title: Sinosphere: Q. and A.: Ning Zhu on the ‘Guaranteed Bubble’ in China’s Economy
item.media:description: Laborers at a construction site in Beijing.
item.description: Professor Zhu, a scholar at the Shanghai Advanced Institute of Finance, says government guarantees have encouraged hazardous levels of leverage as the economy slows.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Voting on European Integration: A Long History of Skepticism
item.media:description: Margaret Thatcher, center, the leader of Britain’s Conservative Party, just days before the Europe referendum in June 1975.
item.description: As Britain prepares to decide whether to remain in the European Union, the history of such referendums offers cautionary lessons.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Vehicle in Convoy of U.S. Ambassador to U.N. Kills Boy in Cameroon
item.media:description: Refugees gathered to see the United States ambassador to the United Nations, Samantha Power, as she visited the Minawao refugee camp in Cameroon on Monday.
item.description: Samantha Power later visited the family of the 7-year-old who was killed after he rushed to see the motorcade hurtling through his village.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: Carnival’s Maiden Voyage to Cuba Draws Ire and Bias Charges
item.media:description: Junior Rodriguez, 28, protested Carnival’s refusal to book Cuban-born passengers on its cruises to Cuba. A Cuban law prevents Cuban-born people from traveling to the island by boat.
item.media:credit: Carl Juste/Miami Herald, via Associated Press
item.description: Cuba does not allow people born on the island to travel there by ship. Some Americans who were born there say that the law discriminates against them.
item.dc:creator: LIZETTE ALVAREZ

item.title: Obama Will Meet With Gulf Leaders. Here’s a Probable Agenda.
item.media:description: President Obama with King Salman of Saudi Arabia in Riyadh last year.
item.description: The president is set to meet with leaders from Saudi Arabia and five other countries to discuss Iran, the Syrian civil war and other regional issues.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Yemen Peace Effort Falters as Houthis Refuse to Attend Talks
item.media:description: Protesters demanding an independent state for southern Yemen rallied on Monday in Aden, a southern port city.
item.description: The rebels accused government-allied forces of violating a truce and said delegates would not engage in negotiations until there was a cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: SAEED AL-BATATI and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: United Nations Memo: Global Debate Over War on Drugs Heads to U.N. General Assembly
item.media:description: Antidrug police officers destroying cannabis plants this month that were discovered in an illegal marijuana plantation at the foot of Seulawah Agam mountain in Aceh Besar, Indonesia.
item.description: A growing insurgency against strict international antidrug treaties will help shape a historic debate at the United Nations this week among world leaders.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Obama Calls on Putin to Help Reduce Violence in Syria After Peace Talks Stall
item.media:description: Staffan de Mistura, the United Nations special envoy for Syria, in Geneva on Monday. He said that the peace process would continue and that “ups and downs” were to be expected.
item.description: Preparing for an overseas visit, President Obama urged President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to press Syria’s leader, Bashar al-Assad, to stop attacks against opposition forces.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Global Health: AIDS Treatment in Haiti Promising for Developing Nations
item.description: A program providing free medicines has produced a survival rate comparable to that of gay men in the United States.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: 2 Captured Russian Men Sentenced to Prison in Ukraine
item.media:description: Capt. Yevgeny Yerofeyev, left, and Sgt. Aleksandr Aleksandrov in court in Kiev, Ukraine, on Monday. Their ranks date from their time in the Russian military. The Russian government said both had resigned from the military before leaving to fight in Ukraine.
item.description: The Russians, captured on a battlefield last year, had been accused of fighting in the separatist war in southeast Ukraine as active-duty Russian soldiers — a claim Moscow denies.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Burundi Is Torturing Prisoners in Crackdown on Dissent, United Nations Says
item.media:description: Heavily armed police officers patrolled in Bujumbura, the capital of Burundi, last week.
item.description: Prisoners had been beaten or burned so severely by the security services that they could not walk unaided, agency’s human rights commissioner said.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: U.S. to Send Military Advisers Closer to Front Lines of ISIS Fight in Iraq
item.media:description: Iraqi forces fired toward positions held by the Islamic State during fighting in the city of Hit last week.
item.description: The move, announced by Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter, puts the Americans closer to the Iraqi soldiers involved in combat, allowing for timely guidance.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Bus Bombing in Jerusalem Wounds 21
item.description: The bombing on Monday afternoon started a fire that spread quickly from one bus to another. Two of the wounded were listed in serious condition, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Letter From Europe: U.S. Comes Up Short on Corporate Transparency
item.media:description: George Osborne
item.description: The disclosures of hidden wealth in the Panama Papers have focused attention on the secrecy offered under American law to offshore companies.
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: Britons Will Be Poorer if They Leave E.U., Government Asserts
item.media:description: Liz Truss, Britain’s environment secretary, and George Osborne, chancellor of the Exchequer, in Bristol, England, on Monday.
item.description: Under one situation, the annual economic output would be $6,100, lower per household if Britain left than if it stayed in the bloc, an estimate critics quickly disputed.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Banker Brother of Malaysian Premier Steps Aside From Posts Amid Inquiry
item.media:description: Nazir Razak, the chairman of CIMB Group Holdings, said he handed out to governing party leaders nearly $7 million he received from his brother, Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia.
item.description: Nazir Razak said he would take a leave of absence from CIMB Group Holdings while his bank examined his handling of nearly $7 million he received from his brother.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Stepanakert Journal: Amid Ethnic Conflict in Nagorno-Karabakh, an Oasis Thrives
item.media:description: A view of Stepanakert, Azerbaijan, the capital of the disputed mountain enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh.
item.description: Support from Armenian émigrés, including many in Southern California, adds a cosmopolitan flair to the tiny republic of Karabakh and its capital.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Israelis Find New Tunnel From Gaza Into Israel
item.media:description: An opening into a tunnel that was exposed by the Israeli military in 2013 near Kibbutz Ein Hashlosha, just outside the southern Gaza Strip. The Israeli military said Monday that a new tunnel into Israel had been discovered.
item.description: The tunnel, the first discovered since the war in 2014, was “neutralized” after it was found in a breakthrough method the Israelis did not specify.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Sinosphere: Twitter’s Chief in China Raises Eyebrows Over Military Past and Résumé
item.media:description: A tourist in Pingyao, China. Many Chinese users of Twitter outside the country reacted harshly to the hiring of Kathy Chen.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Kathy Chen served a stint in the Chinese military and was involved in a venture that was partly owned by the country’s domestic security ministry.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Chinese Parents Outraged After Illnesses at School Are Tied to Pollution
item.description: State TV said that nearly 500 students in eastern China had developed illnesses, a few as serious as leukemia, and that a nearby field had toxins far above limits.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: David Cameron’s Personal Finances
item.media:description: Protesters in Parliament Square, London, earlier this month.
item.description: With a referendum on Europe in the balance, it is not a good time for the prime minister to look like a rich toff.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW D’ANCONA

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Tackling Graft in India
item.description: An identity card program is helping to reduce corruption, but changing cultural norms is a huge task.
item.dc:creator: ANJA MANUEL

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Obama Shouldn’t Trade Cluster Bombs for Saudi Arabia’s Friendship
item.media:description: President Obama with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Nayef, center, and Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, in May 2015.
item.description: Washington is trying to buy off Riyadh with weapons. The results are deadly.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM D. HARTUNG

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: Dispatch from Dakar: ‘Where Is This Flight Going?’ and Other Basic Questions About African Travel
item.media:description: A moldy airplane on the runway in Cameroon.
item.description: In West Africa, getting there is way more than half the battle.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
